Early Access Review

To be fair, this review is written after only 46 minutes into the game. The reason I didn't get further is the game mostly did not work.

I have been following this game on and off since 2008. Off mainly because I never received any emails about the game for seven years now (same email address). I figured the game had just ceased development. I noticed it on Steam recently and I guess they had some development issues and it changed hands. I thought I'd give it a try.

First of all, I have a pretty decent setup:

Intel i7-2600K, ASRock Extreme 77 motherboard
32GB G-Skill 2566 MHz RAM
500GB SSD
Zotac 6GB 980Ti Amp! Edition graphics
Benq XL2420L 144Hz monitor
Windows 7 64-bit Ultimate

The game is apparently capped at 60Hz, which is what it showed in most of the setup and tutorial areas, except when passing through the portal gate to get to the class testing areas. These don't even appear to be instances. All it seems to do is change your appearance for the class you're trying. FPS dropped to about 3-4 fps for several seconds.

First I tried to change the key binds because I'm left-handed and always do in games. The key bind options did not work. They would appear to change when you selected them (except 'Left Ctrl', which exited the window) but they would not take and went back to the defaults when you closed the window (after pressing 'Apply'). So finally I decided to move on using the default keys. I faired no better.

I went into the Warrior area first and I could use basic swing attackes by left-clicking mouse but none of the skills would reliably function. I occassionally got a couple to work but eventually they just stopped doing anything. I left that area and went to Marksman. My avatar did not change to Marksman but remained a Warrior, but I could not use the sword even. I left the area and came back, still a Warrior. After three or four times exitng and entering, I finally changed to a Marksman. None of the skills worked, not even the basic ones.

I did not try the other classes because, by that time, I could see no point. I realized I was never going to play this. Now people may claim this is happening only to me and there must be a problem with my system, but I assure you there is not. I've played hundreds of games and have never found one I cannot play. After seven years of development, this game should be far beyond this point. I don't know how it got Greenlit.

Another thing that is odd in the design you may want to be prepared for: The VERY FIRST thing you must do in creation of a character is choose their name, which is totally backward. You have no idea what the avatars look like, the classes, the customization options, etc. I don't know about you, but when I play an MMO a lot of the name choice is decided on how the character looks. Every MMO I've ever played saves the naming to the very last. And by the way, the customization is very very limited. I don't know if they plan to improve this but if they don't, everyone will look exactly the same, save for their gender.

I'm sorry, I wanted to like this game and recommend it. But I'm only telling you my experiences. I cannot recommmend Otherland.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions. I wish there was a fence between yes and no. Because I would be sitting on it! Overall though I would not recommend the game at this stage of EA.

The Good:
- I like the fact that character customisation is something that happens throughout the game, rather than something that is frontloaded. You give a basic bodyshape at the beginning. However the rest happens ingame. Beards, hair, accessories and all sorts are something you obtain ingame, and the look of your character is fluid.
- The fact you can actually try out various classes ingame at the beginning. Although the current presentation is pretty awful and does little to show off the class differences.

The ambivalent:
- Text is kept to a minimum. You don't have a wall of generic text to read upon recieving a quest. This is good in terms of keeping the flow going. However at the same time it makes the game very shallow. There is not much grabbing me to continue playing for hours on end yet here. I think here just a touch of extra narration and VA work, would really improve this. Overall though I like the way text is kept to a minimum.
- Combat, I like how smooth character movement and jumping is. And combat can look decent, it just currently gives poor feedback. I find ranged characters play better in this regard.
- Graphics, they are passable. At the same time however certainly not good. Particularly skyboxes and backgrounds often look horrible. And at the moment there is a lot of pop-in going on. Given how small the areas are, broken up by loading, there should be far less problems, particularly huge variation in fps. I expect optimisation to improve over time though. I hope textures and backgrounds do as well.

The bad:
- Story is so far shallow and poorly executed. Cutscenes are largely pointless and could have been done away with. Even a minimum of voice acting might do just enough to make it more engaging.
- Quests are highly linear and must be completed. There is no way to progress in the game without doing quests in order so far. Some quests that should be skippable are required. For example you must customise your character to progress. You must decorate and do the USpace (Player home) tutorial to progress. There is no reason that USpace should be required for story progression.
- So far, so MMORPG, and unfortunately I don't see this changing. I think there was a unique opportunity to do something different using Williams properties. Williams describes a cyber world of simulations, and importantly social interaction. A world going beyond simple quests and combat. I think a game that didn't strictly take from Williams work and instead acknowledged the current world would have been interesting, a place not just to game, but to socially interact. Where you could jump into sims with friends and do various activities that weren't all simple combat.

To be sure I expected a typical MMO. At the same time however I hoped they would at least begin to explore different possibilities. So far there is zero evidence of them doing so. In fact socially the game so far is a wasteland. There are very few tools to interact with others. It is generic sci-fi fetch quest MMO. Very much so at the moment I am reminded of the disappointing Matrix Online.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My gameplay hours are the result of trying to immerse myself enough to write a fair review for a German game review website. TL;DR at the bottom

Plot/Intro
Otherland is based on the saga of novels of the same name by Tad Williams.  In the novels, technological advances have created a virtual world accessible to humans through “surgically implanted bio-port interfaces.”  The user is able to travel anywhere and experience anything in a virtual paradise.  But paradise comes at a cost – a sinister entity exists in the virtual world and its presence causes a disease known as the “Tandagore Syndrome,” leaving its victims in a mental coma.

The game begins in a frantic rush to calm the destruction of the Virtual Reality (VR) world, Otherland.  You are met by a mysterious man named Sellars who has summoned your help in stopping the destruction caused by some devious mogul named Felix Jongleur.  After deciding whether you are Bruce or Caitlin Jenner, you are given an opportunity to test each of the 4 classes: Assassin - Energizer - Marksman - Warrior.  All classes have 3 weapons they can store which mimic specializations in other MMOs. You are told that the only way to save Otherland is to destroy a throne beneath a gigantic winged Egyptian looking creature that I can only assume is the virtualized embodiment of Felix.  You succeed in destroying the throne and the world explodes, presumably destroying everything in it.  Seven years later, you awaken in a VR holding zone aptly titled limbo and the story continues with your uncovering of dark conspiracies surrounding Otherland.

Otherland is a bit of a conundrum as least as gameplay is concerned.  Everything expected from an MMO is present in some fashion or another, but there was an unnerving number of issues that forced the opinion that Otherland was rushed.  Tutorials, interface options, user friendly menus, polished mesh’s and textures, efficient quests, targeting systems, etc., were all either noticeably lacking or missing entirely.  Add to that list; absurd mob respawn times, random eternal loading screens, and a deleted character, and the frustrations associated with this release are glaringly obvious.

Is it worth playing? That depends, if you are willing to support a growing project.  Like many games financed through crowd funding, Otherland will take time to perfect.  The absence of Scrooge McDuck gold vaults typically saved for AAA titles, means developers like Drago will have to piecemeal their work.  The unfortunate product of an enormous game and gradual funding is that some elements are postponed.

ProblemsTutorials – At the onset you are given the option to test a fully leveled version of each class before choosing your own.  “Ok cool, familiarization of the classes, right?” No. This premise is great but lacks context.  The player is placed in front of enemies and left to sort out the system, which without a framework ends up being nonstop left clicking and random button pressing.  Including a talent tree with skill explanations, or mouse-over popups for action bar icons would have vastly improved this introduction.

Interface Familiarity – It’s important for players to feel oriented early in gameplay.  Where to click, what to press to bring up a shield or heal, essentially what the symbols on the screen represent.  As mentioned in the tutorial grievances, this was not present.  Additionally, certain keys did not function at the onset (when most people attempt to familiarize themselves) but unexplainably became usable down the line.  For example if you select the player equipment key “P” during the intro and first missions, nothing happens.  A likely assumption is that there is no ability to view the items you have equipped.   But an hour or so into gameplay suddenly “P” accesses the equipment screen.  Another issue is that certain keys don’t always work.  For instance, the PVP battleground menu is opened with “T,” but hitting “T” again does not dismiss the menu.  You have to hit “Esc” and bring up the options menu to close it.

User Friendly Menus – Quest's  “Submit” and “Accept” buttons were off to the left rather than at the bottom.    Scrolling your mouse-wheel to access the hidden text was futile. Instead, the player has to find a faint white scroll tab and drag it down to see the remaining quest description.  Sometimes multiple menus would overlap and complicate legibility as there was no way to move them.  As mentioned in the interface section, certain menus would not even close.

Efficient Quests – The quest tracker is actually well done and the quests were simple enough.  The issue here is more about camera movement and NPC selection. Acceptance of a quest generally requires selecting the quest giver two or three times for the final acceptance of the quest.  Completion of a quest is the same.  Often times you will think you accepted or completed a quest and start running off only to realize the quest doesn’t exist or hasn’t been completed.  This wasn’t so terrible except that there is an over-the-shoulder zoom that occurs each time the quest giver is selected which can become nauseating with Otherlands bright ambiance.

Targeting – Unlike other MMO’s where a mouse icon is present, or where tabbing between friendlies/enemies is available, Otherland opts for an “orient the camera in the right direction to target” system.  Not only is this a faulty targeting system, but it compounds an issue with indistinguishable NPC selections.  You can’t tell if you are targeting the right thing, this will become an issue in end-game content.

Bugs/Respawns/Loading Screens/Eradicated Character – All there.  Did you get your player stuck?  Well there’s no way for you to port out so I guess just wait until an admin shows up or start over with a new character.  Did you just kill that group of bad guys 30 seconds ago? Yep, they missed you.  Ready to enter the binary bar? Too bad, you have to wait forever.  Did you just get your character to level 15?  Congratulations, he’s been eliminated from our servers!!

Redeeming QualitiesDespite the above issues the game is in fact functional and loaded with content.  The shading in Lambda Mall, one of the hub areas of the game, is strikingly similar to a steam punk version of Hong Kong.  The glare of advertisements and television screens obscures your vision when viewed from certain angles.  In 5-Isle, the land of the elements, the feel that you have entered a VR rendering of a Chinese farmland is comfortably fake.  Otherland’s launch screen is beautiful and, when accompanied by some smooth synthetic jazz, is reminiscent of the garden ponds from the citadel in Mass Effect.  The music was always suited to a region and appropriately complimented the ambiance.  Sound effects were properly implemented, helping to enhance immersion. Quests are plentiful and intuitive.  Most importantly the designers made sure not to have players running in circles, rather quests advance players through each zone without tiring them with unchanged scenery.

TL:DROtherland is loaded with content, but it lost me.  In its current state it simply feels rushed...like they stepped up to the plate hoping to knock out a present day AAA MMO.  Too many frustrations will distract you from the game. If Early Access addresses some of these issues then player satisfaction will rise.  There is a gem inside that hunk of rock, Otherland just needs a few rounds of polishing

This is not the best thing to put right after the whole begining area folks.

The overall feel of the game I liked. The setting is...interesting and unique. The combat is different enough..but something feels off about it. I can't pin-point my finger on it..but it needs tweeking or something. I wouldn't call it bad, however it could be better. I feel like it needs to be more responsive or something. Maybe it was my ping bouncing but it felt off.

The questing feels typical but not too bland. Average at best as far as I could tell.

I wish that I could recommend this title because it has the something that kind of has an allure to it in my opinion..but just the things that I mentioned and a few things that I have not are keeping me back from voting yes. Maybe in time this could change.

Many reviews are dated to complain about things that have been fixed. Also many reviews have little to no hours played which seem less legitimate IMO. My review has over 300+ hours played, and though yes I am a cultist who enjoyed the novels, the game in itself is good too. I won't lie, it is an E.A. and it is unfortunate that we can't experience the whole game just yet, but the devs are working hard and I look forward to official release. I have equated this game to a dusty corvette. Once the polishing is done it will shine, for now if you play you must have a bit of patience. The devs have been extremely helpful and communicative via tickets, forums, and real time chat by friending them on steam. They've brought out two holiday events to help keep the current playerbase satisified. It is a small playerbase atm but that also means it's a tight knit community that's very helpful. Moderators are also pretty cool, even one joined us in our multiwebcam tinychat session we had one night. More details are as follows:

Combat: many complain but we've seen improvements over time, such as suggested on the forums sticky modification and crosshair mods too. They have plans to do an overhaul to it, which I am personally not interested in but it seems the majority is.

Storyline: I am biased because I read the books and it makes sense to me, but I have heard those that haven't read them get lost in the plot.

Player Housing: I love the idea of having pvp like taking over of one's home so that harvesting eDna and putting up NPC guards will protect it. This feature is not implemented yet.

Crafting: It is rough at the moment, no real use for it as drop gear is better and vendor pots are better. I assume they will improve this in time.

Multiverse: Love this system! It gives an option to put real variety in a game. Rather than those other mmorpgs where you are stuck in one themed environment. This game being VR based gives endless possibilities to the future simulations. Can't wait to see where they go with it.

Graphics: many have said they are stunning and I agree. Some parts seem dated, but with my fav mmorpg ever having been SWG I don't nitpick.

Customization: Every one of my clanmates/friends has a different appearance. Definitely better than the other mmorpgs where it appears clones are running around because so many look exactly alike.

Clans/Clanwars: most of these features are not implemented yet, the clanspace is pretty sweet though.

Classes: yes there are just 4 (for now, but I've seen evidence there are more coming) but there are 2 stances for each giving advanced strategic players a chance to actually use their skills vs. the tab target buttom mashing that some mmorpgs offer.

Business Model: This is the cheapest mmorpg I've ever played. I usually play FTP and spend a ton in the cashshop, or subscription and end up paying monthly for two of them. BTP is new to me, but wow I feel like I've gotten such a steal for my money.

System Requirements: This game runs, not optimally but runs, even on my cheapo pawnshop laptop. Which is nice when I am at college away from my leeter gaming desktop.

Difficulty: As of now it's pretty easy to solo most of the game and level up fast. The devs have said they will modify this, so hurry up, jump in, and level while it's easy and quick :)

p.s. a lot more info in the guides I & others have created: http://steamcommunity.com/id/frayena/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides

The Otherland book series captivated my father, and it was he who brought this game to my attention. He's actually been keeping me somewhat aware of this MMO adaptation for some time now, which is odd, because he rarely plays games himself. If he was this intrigued by a game that he most likely wouldn't play, then, I thought, the story must be quite interesting, and so I believed this was surely worth a go.

Unfortunately, as you can see by my thorough lack of game time, I'm not particularly able to review the game. I have tried on 3 separate occasions to play, and every time, even in the tutorial area, I am met with ridiculous ping spikes of 500+, shoddy gameplay (perhaps caused by the ping, though who knows), and crashes. For context, I am on the EUW server, living in the U.K., and have no issue with my connection in other games.

As an example of the shoddy gameplay, while trying out the Marksman class in the tutorial (which gives you access to all or most of your abilities), I would fire at an enemy from range. If I tried to kite them, as you'd expect from a ranged class, they would reset back to their original positions, regenerate all of their HP, and evade any attacks while they moved back. Odd, I thought, perhaps they have a specific aggro range. Maybe if I try kiting them around their original spawn point, instead of far back like I did last time, it'll work? No, they still reset. As a ranged class, I have to sit in melee while they whale on me. This would be solved by a tank, of course, but it's still quite ridiculous that I can't kite.

For all I know though, it's only the tutorial enemies that act this way. I have never played for more than 10 minutes in a single session, as I always crash.

I'm not sure yet if I'll request a refund, or simply wait and hope it gets better, but right now, this game is not playable for me. I can't recommend a game that I can't play.

The best way to describe this game is, somebody made it, with good intentions im sure, but bit of way more then they could chew, and it shows.

I am trying to keep in mind that this game is in early access and that things can and will most likely improve over time, I just don't see this getting to a point where I could stand to play for more then an hour without getting bored, that is not great for a MMO witch bank on basically being a time syncs.

A few points this game could improve on are.

The Visuals.
Granted I only saw 3 zones. The first being the basic tutorial area where I could customize my character, try every class and choose it and not much else. The second being the newbie area or starting zone, where I got to fight for real, (more on combat later) the area look like it might have been knocked up in a few days maybe a little longer if you take into account the 6-7 models that the level designer copy and pasted to break up the literally flat rectangle pond that the level is comprised off. This whole starting zone looked just boring with any interesting landscape off into the skybox.

Then I got to the first vaguely interesting part of the game so far, where I zone into a big digital city, of witch I spend the last 20 mins. This was OK because you can sort of justify a city being made out of cubes of gray but even then the quality was very poor. I would like to say more but literally it was so plain that there is not a whole lot else to say.

The General Look to the game was poor too, I put this game on Ultra and the textures are very low resolution, blurry fluorescent lines cover your character with some generic scifi looking gear skinned over it, the weapons had a few different models but all have the same effects. And the game just does not look up to scratch for the power of the engine. In a word this game looks old, So lets move on too...

Game play
To say that the combat in this game was simple would make clicker games seem complicated, there were some skill attacks but none of these did any real damage compared to the autoattack, in witch you hold your mouse button down in the direction of a NPC and it slowly dies while kicking you in the shins, none of the combat felt remotely satisfying. The targeting system was what ever you put in the middle of the screen, there is no movement or dodging that needed to be done, no blocks or defensive ability apart from a weak knockback that mainly just slowed you down from killing things. There was no customization in skills that i could see and gear was generic enough for me not to care about it.

Overall the only thing i can think to say is that I would not recommend anyone buy this in its current state, and unless this game drastically changes in the next few years i not sure i will even give it another chance.

Early Access Review

I'll start by saying that I rarely write reviews on games unless I have a very strong opinion (for better or worse). Otherland is one of those games.
I consider myself a veteran MMO player, as well as a fairly casual gamer. While I appreciate some guidance and instruction, I've played enough to find my way around without having my hand held.
At this point in time, I can't bring myself to recommend this game, and here's why:
Short version:
Pros:
*Interesting concept - worlds with different themes. That's what had attracted me.
*Try classes out before selecting.
(Short list since I'm not through the tutorial yet)

Cons:
*Little to no instruction in the tutorial (except for movement)
*No skills page to learn what your combat moves actually do. This is a deal breaker for me. (Edit: You do get access to this after choosing your class)
*Don't seem to be able to re-arrange the skills in my hotbar to where I want. What is intuitive for someone else might not be for me. Granted, I didn't pay a huge amount of attention to this, but given the only way to access skill tooltips is in the ESC menu, it likely won't work. Another deal breaker. (Edit: found it. CTRL key for anyone interested)
*No traditional account creation. Had to wait for an automated activation email.
*MASSIVE ping rate - 700+ms - and I'm in Europe playing on the EU server -.-

Long version:
Upon starting up Otherland, I found myself confronted with a typical ELUA and a fill-in for my email address. Entering my email informs me that I'll be emailed account activation instructions shortly. OK, that's different. After about 15-20 minutes wait, I finally received the activation email. In I go, and find myself with an androgynous... android? avatar and an NPC with a trophy over his head. No interaction instructions, eh? Fine. Start running the gamut of usual MMO controls and stumble across the action button. Get some basic instruction on movement and a little avatar customization, then away we go to the class training area.

Four portals, one to test out each class before choosing your favorite. Great! No regret for picking one that doesn't suit you later. Unfortunately, there is also absolutely no instruction for combat basics or class descriptions. Not everyone reads player tutorials or class descriptions on websites, guys. Ok, so I try to check out the skills to see which does what. Skills page? Where? No? Had to go into the pause menu to get the cursor and hover over each skill. Really? So far I haven't seen much difference between the four classes. Root grenades for the ... what was it... Energizer? didn't seem to work, and I lost patience before figuring out the Assassin's sneaking. I have yet to actually choose my class and plan to give them another run, but so far I don't see myself playing this much if at all.

The concept of different themes in each world was an intriguing one, and I hope I'll find more intriguing things if I can bring myself to play beyond the tutorial... otherwise Otherland will be one more Early Access regret purchase...

Update: Completed the tutorial and selected my class. Now have access to the skills page, inventory, and all that jazz. Woo. Followed up with the 'Rescue us from the corrupted sim' quest line, then got sent to the area after. Where I was stuck in a loading screen. I wasn't impressed before, and I'm still not that impressed. The four classes feel pretty stale. Your usual shoot'em up or hack'n'slash types, but the ping rate is still so terrible that it makes no difference. I feel like I'm poking mobs with a butter knife... My advice: don't waste your time or money unless there are some major changes since this review.

Otherland is a strange curiousity in a world of somewhat post-MMORPGs. The story and environments are varied from Tron-esque cyberpunk cities to Asian-themed areas. The whole game makes me feel like I'm playing as a player playing an online game. Is that weird to say? Probably. It's a weird game. It's definitely not bad by any means, and I think it's one of the most interesting MMOs I've played in a market of stagnation. The devs try really hard to keep the game current and interesting. There's some passion there that I really do respect.

The only thing I can't get over is the combat system. It's incredibly clunky and feels awkward to play. Enemies seem to take -forever- to kill, as my warrior archetype at least. It's not inherently bad, but it's nothing compared to action combat systems like Tera or Neverwinter or even Guild Wars 2. I really hope the devs can take a look at the combat in these other games and improve on the hit detection, hitboxes, and general feel of the the combat because right now it's just not that great.

TL;DR it's a fun little MMO diversion with an interesting world that needs more players, but it definitely has issues in the combat area.

Did not realize this was in 'early access' phase. Very glitchy, too many bugs to report. Constantly getting stuck in geometry (had to delete one character that couldn't get unstuck), dissappearing mobs & NPC's, water effects in inappropriate places (splashing footfalls on top of a tower!?), and balancing of difficulty needs MUCH more work. Basically unplayable as yet. Will give it another go when it's in final release.

So far the interface and quests seem like a copy of every other run-of-the-mill MMO. In this case, this actually works to the player's advantage if they're familiar with MMORPGs, because there is absolutely no explanation in-game of how anything works. I really haven't seen anything (other than graphics - WAY WAY WAYYY TOO MUCH BLOOM!) that would set this apart in the genre.

I like the concept, but there doesn't seem to be anything that hasn't already been done to death in the MMORPG genre. Not worth playing at this stage, but will come back for another try when it's ready. Only recommending 'yes' because the game isn't finished yet, and 'no' doesn't seem quite fair because, again, it's not finished.

It's early access, it has problems. If you want a smooth, content complete gameplay experience- don't buy this. It is clunky and definitely has some optimization issues. Only time will tell if the developers will be able to actually get this to a launch worthy state.

However, I like it. The world is cool, it has a sort of Phantasy Star kind of feel. Combat wise it is much like Tabula Rasa, FPS with lock on targeting. Quest dialogue is never more than a few lines of text, if that, so the story does not exactly draw one in. But the general idea is unique, you are playing in a computer world and travel among different simulations with varying themes from the far east, to lush planets, with a cyper punk city serving as the main hub. So far there are a lot of missions, housing, clans, and the crafting system just got overhauled.

You never know with early access titles, but if you have $20 you want to risk and hunger for a sci-fi mmo that is different from the mainstream- give it a try. Just understand what you're in for...

The downside, imo, is there have been ongoing technical issues. Not surprising, all things considered. and no worse than I have seen in 15 years of Everquest. There is also the matter of refinement being needed in text and quest dialog for consistency and clarification. Also not surprising considering where game development has taken place, and the fact that original development ended some time ago and more recently was picked up by a new team.
The upside has multiple aspects.
Graphics are excellent.
Content is wideranging and expanding with development.
Quest tasks minimize repetitive actions and advance without enormous time sinks being involved.
Problems are addressed in an expedient manner, and dev's responsiveness far exceeds any I have experienced in the past with other companies.
The potential is readily apparent in the scope of the existing world at present, and bodes well for future development.
I have 90 hours played, primarily as a marksman character on the NA server, and have thoroughly enjoyed the game thus far. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.

Originally I'm really not an MMO Fan for a lot of reasons. Clunky gameplay, dated graphics, no lore, stale questlines, and rehashed mechanics... Well it seems Otherland succeeds in blowing all those stereotypes out of the water, offering a very interesting and refreshing take on the MMO genre.

Otherland takes place in a proteiform virtual reality (some will fondly remember TRON or Ready:Player One) where several worlds are interconnected. SciFi, Medieval, Cyberpunk, ye olde Fantasy... What's great about Otherland in that regard is that it manages to give you a huge variety of places to explore and lores to delve into, but everything is connected by a red-thread storyline. It's not just variety for the sake of variety, it is, properly speaking, Universe Building, in all its coherence. One might add, it is all done with respect to the original works it is based on.

I have to admit, the setting is what seduced me firsthand about the game, but I also ended up liking the mechanics and gameplay, even though I'm usually turned off by the standard MMO experience. As I said, the Otherland experience has nothing to do with Classic MMOs. Controls are tight, intuitive and responsive. Combat strikes just the right balance between Tactics and Action. Think Mass Effect without the active pause, or Gears of War with deeper class-based strategical depth.

Customization is also a real forte in this game. Where other MMOs will have you wear palette-swapped armors on predetermined characters, Otherland allows you to tweak your character's base model to your liking, and craft completely unique gear through an innovative Digital DNA systems. Oh and you can craft NPCs too. Yes. You can craft NPCs.

Now, not everything about Otherland is great, and I have to admit, even though it looks good, and the artistic direction really nails the different vibes of the worlds, it's really heavy on light and particle effects for my taste, and you won't be able to benefit from the best graphical performance on lower-end machines, where other MMOs usually run without problems. But once again, OL has nothing in common, for better or worse.

One thing is also worth noting, OL is really polished in comparison from other  Early Access titles (i'd say more than EA titles too but that would be a bad pun). Can't wait to see what devs have in store for the following months, provided the servers hold!

Okay: Its a yes from me.

Warning - This mini review ignores standard mmo launch woes. I am only previewing the content that works, ignoring the launch bugs such as lag, server disconnections, crashing and other such things. I will update this later if these do not get addressed.

---------------

1) Combat  - Its pretty fun when it works but the four classes are like four different games entirely. The combat can be clunky, awkward and at times downright impossible to play with. I am also worried that there will be zero customization, at the moment everyone has the same class and abilities so I can see no way to be a different Energizer to anyone else, except gear.

Marksman is very clunky ,you lock to a single target while shooting and its hard to swap targets. Did not feel like there was any weight behind the weaponry, impact was not visible. Hard to tell what was going on.

Meanwhile, Warrior feels very slow and heavy. Attacking is a slow, steady process, doesn't seem to have any weight to the attacks at all.

Opposite that is Assasin, incredibly fast paced attacks and stealth and your traditional rogue nature.

And finally, The Energizer. Some sort of wierd techno-gunmage, and the class i picked. Most responsive, VERY pretty to watch, and easiest to use for me. It was the only one I felt had any feedback to attacks.

Pros:

Fun when it works
Very pretty gameplay wise
Satisfying when you win an encounter

Cons:

Exceptionally clunky at times
Not fun when it doesnt work
Very difficult to pick up combat
Not easy to learn a class
ZERO class customization.


2) Gameplay

Standard quest stuff really for a mmo. Go here, kill that, rescue this and do that. Not seen anything special here in the question as of yet, but the quests are given a little bit of fresh life by simply being in this strange setting. Rescuing 'player' npcs and reading the dialogue was pretty interesting.

I hope to see more quests of a different nature as I progress. The story itself was pretty interesting and gripping for me, too. I like it.


3) Visuals

They are very pretty. They are stylised, and very pretty once you get out of the tutorial zone. It has a definate VR/sci-fi feel to it which is what they are aiming at. All in all, i am very happy with the visual aesthetics of the game.

4) Tutorials

Needs an overhaul.

One of the worst tutorials i have ever encountered for an online game. The explanations are short, not expandable or in depth and often they seemed to leave me questioning what exactly I was supposed to be doing at that step, and/or what that particular explanation even meant or referred to. Case in point? I am still completely clueless as to the SEED system and the research lab for my apartment and i dont know what it does. I think i must have missed a dialogue box here.

All of the parts of the tutorial could be smoother, with longer dialogue and they DEFINATELY need a 'for more information click here' thing that will expand and fully explain every system as it appears.

5) Audio

Very cool sounds and music. Nothing else to say here, although the healing sound effect did get particularly annoying after awhile.

6) Customization

There was a suprising lack at the start, but then once i completed the tutorial zone i was allowed into an advanced shop which was awash with many, many customization options from changing races to Lizard, Magma, Rock, Metal, Cyborg and Bird skins to colors, hairstyles and all the good stuff you expect to see. Not as advanced as say, elder scrolls online but pleasing enough.

7) New Player Orientation (this is not tutorial)

Very, very poor. If you are waking into this game with no outside knowledge of the books, you are going in blind. I understood very little of what was going on, where I was or anything at all really. There absolutely must be an explanation for somebody who has not read the books, because inevevitably online games draw people in who may not read the background information outside of a game.

That said, i enjoy exploration and the unknown so I had a blast absorbing the world but many new players may simply just disengage and leave rather than attempt to understand or get involved.

8) Summary, or TLDR:

Fun setting, interesting gameplay, average combat. If you like sci-fi-fantasy or have read the books, give it a go. Very, very well priced for what it is as a buy to play title. I do not regret my purchase, I hope to see more updates and bug fixes as we go. I am looking forwards to checking out more of the game.

Early Access Review

It's not bad, but not great either. I like the concept of a virtual multiverse. I think with a little more love from the Devs, this could be a pretty good game. Obviously this is Early Access and the Devs are probably hard at work to fix the issues that the community points out (well, at least I hope they are).

Things I felt needed work:
-The combat felt kind of clunky at times and the targeting system can use a little more work. Switching targets didn't feel fluid and often hindered combat.
- There would be times where I felt the skill buttons were a little unresponsive.
- You AI friends didn't fell like they helped all that much while the enemy AI were very quick to swarm and overwhelm you.
- Some minor graphical issues that I'm sure future optimization plans the Devs have will fix.
- I had a cutscene not play for me in the 5square(?) area. The part where they were going to have the festival after you gathered all the villagers.
- Character customization could use some work as well. Allowing us to zoom in and out, or turn our characters would be appreciated.
- Some spelling mistakes in the conversations.
- Would be nice if NPCs can be voiced in the future.

Things that I really liked:
- Good amount of customization.
- Good graphics.
- Big Sci-fi and Fantasy MMO fan, so that was really cool to see both mashed up in one game.
- You get a home, and it's customizable!!
- Story seems pretty cool, so far.

Again, it's early access, so I'm sure there will be lots of fixes addressing a lot of the issues I've mentioned and probably once I didn't know about. Honestly, the game has a lot of potential and if they can smooth out the rough edges, this can really turn into something pretty fun to play. My opinion though, if you do plan to buy one of the Editions, stick with the starter or the delux, unless you really want the following DLCs:

Mummy Skin DLC
Cyborg Skin DLC
+12 Inventory Slots DLC
+2 Character Slot DLC
+15000 Bits DLC
+4000 Credits DLC
Collectors Edition Special Bar

Not all that important. The only thing really good that comes out of it are the bits and credits you get. They did state that they are only optional and they will not force you to have to buy the DLC to play future updates. One time fee to access the game and that's it! I won't lie though. I did buy the delux, but only because I wanted to support the game.

Review for 4 hours in (please bare that in mind as you read)....

Great concept - Yes (rare to see a sci-fi much less a cyber-punk MMO these days)

Graphical apeal - Yes (somewhat stylized but they are quite nice to look at)

Needs some work to be finished properly - absolutely (this devs are saying that although this is being sold as early access it is somewhat in what used to be a CBT. The game is definately playable, but still has a quite a few bugs, and is still in need of some serious polish).

Things that need to be addressed (IMO):
1. Server stability: they are not fully available at this point
2. FPS/Ping: frame-rate and ping are still very bouncy.  I have encountered a LOT of lag spikes and crazy frame-rate fluxuations at all video settings (from fair all the way to ultra I only experience about a 10 fps difference but the spikes are terrible).  Just needs some optimization which will usually come after full release and NVIDIA (or the other graphics cards) get a hold of it to create the patches.
3. Voice acting: so the sound on this game is great, but the literal lack of ANY voice acting from the NPCs is annoying to say the least, and fully takes away from the game.  I am hoping that this will be added with the full release of the game but have not read into the game enough at this point to know for sure (FFXIV ARR had no voice acting all the way through CBT, it is often times the last thing added to a game).
4. Quests: The quests (at least through the first 10 levels and a bit beyond that) are VERY linear.  The devs have stated that this is a BIG game so I am expecting that to change.
5. Skills: also quite linear with little variation as to how you customize your play-style.  More varation would be greatly appreciated, Especially for those that prefer PVP (as it does not really play like a skill based game i.e. FPS, variation is the spice of life).
6. Classes: only 4 classes?!? Hope there is a chance to branch out further down the line.  Once again variation would be greatly appreciated.

All this being said, it is solid MMO with a lot of potential that I plan to keep playing for the near future.  For the $17 price tag and no subscription nor a reliance on a cash shop it is a great bargain!  Keep it up devs; please don't dissapoint!!!

Otherland has had a rough start, as any MMO usually does.
Please disregard any negative reviews talking about being stuck or specific bugs, they obviously don't understand Early Access and should not be reviewing this game.

Let's talk about the state of the game at the moment.
Drago Entertainment has stated they would like to keep Otherland in EA for 6 months.
Right now, Otherland will let you go to about level 40. There's no current end-game content.

The 6 months (or more) that Otherland will remain in early access will mostly be a bug/polish phase for the MMORPG. This means IF YOU BUY THIS GAME, DO NOT EXPECT IT TO BE POLISHED. IF YOU WANT A POLISHED GAME, GO BUY A GAME THAT IS NOT IN EARLY ACCESS.


Environment

Otherland is different in that you are a simuloid or essentially a piece of code. Which allows you to go into a variety of worlds and opens up many options not typically available to standard humans.

Combat/Classes

Classes are pretty basic in this game. Total of 4 classes that can each have 2 different roles.
Combat needs more polish and tweaking, it can be frustrating at times, but by no means buggy". It just feels a bit clunky in some cases. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Otherland Review

Introduction

Otherland is an Unreal-powered Action MMORPG based on the highly acclaimed novels by Tad Williams, being developed by Drago Entertainment.

The game is very much a work in progress; currently in an early release state on STEAM under a 'pay-to-play' model. It offers three levels, or options if you like, with varying numbers of credits which can be spent ingame on costumes and other useful but fairly standard fare like extra inventory slots, character slots, etc.


Good bits

Graphics - very bright and cheerful. The characters, in spite of the relatively low number of useful customisation (vanity!) options at present, look good and move nicely and there's an amazing variety of shapes and sizes of npc's giving us a lot of hope for future player customisation. Interestingly, the game allows you to change every aspect of your characters appearance pretty much whenever you feel like it.

There's a good variety of weapons and the very welcome ability to use any weapon you find. That means that a ranged character can have a backup melee weapon available and your melee character has the ability to pull mobs with a ranged hit. That's a really nice feature. You can actually slot three weapons, which have various effects, and swap between them at will and you get regular upgrades as you progress through the story.

It's possible to wear any costume/armour item you find. Of course, there's not always much point but being able to do so makes a very nice departure from the standard MMO system where 90% of the drops are useless to you. The npc's offer you quest rewards which are upgrades to your armour as you progress through the story, as they do for the weapons.

There's an attentive and friendly team working on the game which interacts well with the community. They're monitoring, and taking part in, discussions on both STEAM and the official Drago forums. They're open to new ideas and suggestions and doing a great job of keeping people informed of progress with bugs etc. which they are clearing at an impressive rate.

So far at least, a friendly and helpful community seems to be springing up - certainly on the forums, ingame I can't really comment since I've been soloing so far but I've had no negative issues at all with other players.


Not so good bits

Combat feels a bit clunky for an MMO. It sometimes feels more like an old FPS model. Maybe a result of using the unreal3 engine...I don't know. It's not bad and I was sitting on the fence a bit, not sure whether to put this in the 'not so good bits' section because it does work quite well. It's just not as fluid as most other MMO's, lets just say it still needs some work.

At present Otherland is a bit short on quests. The ones that exist give you a very linear progression up to about level 35, and quests are where the bulk of the exp comes from so thats pretty much as far as you can get without grinding.

Some confusion over powers, quests, etc. where things aren't explained terribly well and quest markers over npc's heads but not shown on the maps lead to 'additional exploration'. That can be a pain when you're trying to work out what you're supposed to be doing but there's plenty to explore in some areas and it's nice to get around and see what the developers have been creating :)

Character customisation (described as 'from tiny to huge') is a bit limited at the moment. You actually get from slightly larger than average to slightly smaller than average...certainly nowhere near the range of sizes the npc's enjoy. And vanity (costume) items are hidden by the armour rendering them pretty much useless at present unless you plan on standing around Lambda Mall and not doing any fighting!


Summary

A long way to go yet, lots of bugs which are being worked on and the character customisation isn't as flexible as some other MMO's but for me it's fun and I'm enjoying playing the game and trying things out.

It's worth saying again that the 'not so good bits' are due mainly to the early state of the game in its development and are being worked on. I've only been playing for a few days and I've seen some major improvements already, the development team really are getting on top of things.

Overall, after having played for nearly 30 hours, I quite like the game. If you can cope with the inevitable issues that exist in all games at this stage of development then I'd recommend giving it a try.

Early Access Review

Otherland is a creative adaptation of the Tad Williams books with the same title. It's about the world near the end of the 21st century, in which virtual platforms are fully integrated into everyday life.

The overall experience playing Otherland in the first days has been, apart from the somewhat typical early access and  launch problems, surprisingly positive.

The game lacks some polish and some of the dialogues and quest texts could use some brushing up, but I kind of expected stuff like this at this stage.

What keeps me engaged and what has drawn me to the game in the first place is the game world. I haven't read the books (yet) and the game doesn't exactly overflow with information during the first hours of playing, but the science-fiction/virtual reality setting looks suprisingly fresh and imaginative. The graphics, while not state-of-the-art, are very detailed and - together with some really nice music and sound effects - provide a very immersive atmosphere.

Combat is relatively easy, at least as a Marksman. The targeting and target locking didn't really click with me initially but the general gameplay feeling of jumping around shooting normal and special arrows at stuff is similar to what I had in other MMOs with similar ranged classes.

There were still quite some bugs, but fortunately most could be resolved by relogging.

The game looks like it offers a lot in terms of customization. I also liked the fact that you get housing in an early stage of the game already.

Overall, this game so far is in pretty good shape for an early access game in a lot of areas while needing some work on the quests, UI and bugs mainly. I haven't tested group play yet, but the 4 pretty clear archetype classes pretty much suggest what to do I guess. The Marksman feels like fun so far and I really feel like exploring this world some more.

Initial impressions from an older player. Otherland was originally announced under a different developer in 2008. Since then it has had a troubled history and now Drago Entertainment (it's new owners) are trying to finish this Action MMO. Many, may not have heard of Drago Entertainment before but they were involved in another Action MMO called Grimeland and a few other published games. Grimeland looked very promising but the publishers pulled out and that was basically that.

Firstly, it is more in a true late Alpha / early Beta stage with some of the fundemental game mechnics in place and others seem to be in flux. The graphics use UE3 and althrough a little old looking it is a pretty, colorful MMO with some nice varied zones. The gameplay seems to be typical but a slightly slow Action MMO style. There is crafting and housing now plus other aspects in the pipeline. Much of this needs to be fleshed out.

Otherland had been in development for a number of years, firstly under RealU and now under Drago. It comes to EA in a rather unstable state but is playable, if you are willing to be patience. The developers seem to be active on the Steam forums and in bug hunting, but it seems they have a big job in front of them. It will be interesting in seeing how Drago come to terms with the base code developed by the original developers RealU, as there is talk of Otherland only staying in EA for another six months.

It is too early to really review Otherland at the moment. Maybe, In a month and we can see how the developers and Otherland progress, so we can get a better idea for the future. For now, this Action MMO is very interesting yet has conventional in-game mechanics but brings a nice refreshing style to the grahics. Fun can be had, but for now expect a lot of rough edges which the developers seem to be working to smooth. Overland is a bit of a gamble (at this time) but I do not regret purchasing it. :)

I was able to put in a few hours as an Energizer this afternoon. I know a lot of people have been flaming about the Early Release issues, but those of us who have gone through old school WOW releases or any other game release in modern history know that launch day is going to be glitchy. I have been watching this game for some time and had really high expectations for the devs to live up to.

The first thing to note is that the Unreal Engine is a great platform and the graphics have really stood up well. The game is quite nice looking and if you are savy you will notice the little icon at the top of the Metamorph screen so you can make your toon a bit more custom even if it is just a simuloid for now. (Don't worry there are more options later - you are not stuck blue forever.)

Movement is pretty nice as well. I recently played a more polished game that felt completely awful when compared to Otherland. The A and D keys are bound to strafe and movement felt really grounded to me. The jumping animation is slick and collision detection is mostly in tact. I imagine there will be some fine tuning so I am happy with it - it is EA so there will be a lot of clean up as we explore and help report issues.

The combat is pretty fun. I found myself just blasting everything mindlessly because it was so enjoyable. Some may complain that it isn't as fast paced or [enter complaint here] but I loved it. Perhaps it is because I picked the best class in the game though. /wink I highly recommend new players take a moment to review the wiki for interface commands and combat at the very least so you know what to expect. There is a tutorial zone but there are no annoying popup tooltips or other tutorials to hold your hand or walk you through stuff.

The community I spent my time with were like instant family and I can't wait to interact with them more in the future. I am sure when the typical haters move along as they always do, we will be left with some really great people to enjoy the game with.

I didn't run into any hiccups / glitches or problems that would make me walk away from such a cool game. I think we are pretty spoiled with all recent game releases where the games were in beta for ages or released in Korea or other countries well before we got our hands on them. Early Access Review

The good:

-This game has a remarkably well detailed and unique game world. Whoever is designing the set pieces and assets is very talented.
-The music is very well done and sets the mood for the game extremely well.
-The main story is interesting and this game will set itself apart from other MMOs if they focus on the plot instead of tedious World of Warcraft style quests.
-For an MMO launch there are few game breaking bugs so far and very quick server queues.

The bad:
- It is an MMO made by a (relatively) small team and is in early access. There are a few bugs/typos although fewer than many other much larger MMOs at launch.
- Like many recent MMOs there seems to be no reason whatsoever to associate with other players, combined with the theme of this game (virtual reality) it is easy to feel like you're playing an unfinished singleplayer game.
-All of the cool character customization options seem to be locked by cash currency. This causes most players you see to look very similar until they get unique armors.
-The skills seem relatively low impat which is weird in an action combat game. Every skill is basically deal a bit of damage" oftne times not even higher than auto attack.  The combat is very fast paced so having all skills basically do the same thing feels weird. I expect this will be worked out over time.
- The extremely detailed gameworld is somewhat limited by having the areas the player can access be only a small arena. They show you pictures of all these cool buildings in the background but you can not enter very much of them at all. The design is so cool it makes me want to explore more than I am able to.



Summary:
This is a very creative game by a clearly skilled team and I am very excited to see what direction they take it in. If you're expecting "The Next WoW" you might be disappointed but I wouldn't be shocked if this game attracts a core of die hard fans and grows into a unique MMO experience."
